item.description:
You have to walk the old Moseley family estate along the Merrimack River to believe it. The full grounds include 480 acres with the ruins of a 19th century estate and gardens, rolling hills, enormous trees, and in-season, the state’s largest mountain laurel display. The scenery moves swiftly from riverside views, to deep pine woods, to open meadows – with lots of hidden spots once reserved for the rich and famous.

You may be surprised by the extent and crumbling beauty of the land and surviving outbuildings. There are extraordinary trails, but no posted explanation whatsoever about the family that once owned this rambling acreage. The Harvard Alumni page is the source for the information that follows.

History of Maudslay
The Harvard Alumni page is the source for the information that follows. It seems that the former Fredrick Moseley Estate was originally called "Maudesleigh" and was built atop an early 19th century farm. There were up to 40 staff and 30 structures including separate houses for the head gardener, coachman and estate forester. Most of the newer buildings were built from 1895 to 1910. The 72-room mansion was demolished in 1955. Landscape archtect Martha Brookes Hutcheson was among the first three women members of American Society of Landscape Architects. There were extensive gardens, extensive stone walls, many cold frames and greenhouses, a large bunker, an animal cemetery and an enormous rhododendron collection that blooms annually.

All of the above information is borrowed, for the most part, word for word, from the following website, should you like to read more: http://www.seacoastnh...

About the Walk
We will start the hike at 9:10. This walk will be about 3 to 4 miles long. We will move at a slow pace and we will stop at times to enjoy our surroundings. For a trail map, use the following link: http://www.mass.gov/d...

Based on your feedback, we will go to Michael's Harborside Restaurant following the walk. The lower priced entrees tend to be around $10. There is a variety of surf and turf to choose from. I have made a reservation for 1:00 PM. As such, please let me know in advance if you plan on coming on the walk and not to lunch afterward.

What to Bring
Please wear hiking boots or sneakers. Water, a snack, binoculars and a camera would also be good. There is an automated machine in the parking area- Please be sure to bring exactly $2 in cash for parking in case the machine has run out of change.

Getting There
Maudslay State Park
For those with a GPS, the parking lot is located between 85 and 89 Curzon Mill Rd. in Newburyport, MA. If you don't have a GPS, please use mapquest or some other mapping program. I have included directions from I-95.

1. From I-95, merge onto STOREY AVE/RT-113 W via EXIT 57 toward W. NEWBURY. 0.8 mi
2. Turn RIGHT onto GYPSY LN/HOYTS LN. 0.6 mi
(I believe the sign is for Hoyts Ln)
3. Turn right onto CURZON MILL RD. 100-200 ft.
4. 87 CURZON MILL RD is on the RIGHT.

So the parking lot is diagonally across the street from the Park Headquarters building, a historic white house. The restrooms are located in a little cement building at the back of the parking lot. Here is the phone # for the park: 978 465-7223

Michael's Harborside Restaurant
Located at One Tournament Wharf, Newburyport, MA 01950. 978-961-0477
Directions from Maudslay to Michael's:
1. Head east or take a right out of the
parking area on to Curzon Mill Rd toward Daniel Lucy Way 0.2 mi
2. Slight left at Pine Hill Rd 0.7 mi
3. Continue onto Ferry Rd 0.8 mi
4. Continue onto High St 1.6 mi
5. Turn left at Market St 0.2 mi
6. Continue onto St Tournament Wharf
Destination will be on the right 0.1 mi

I look forward to seeing you there!
